abstract: <jats:p>Complex genetic disorders are a result of a combination of genetic and nongenetic factors, all potentially interacting. Machine learning methods hold the potential to identify multilocus and environmental associations thought to drive complex genetic traits. Decision trees, a popular machine learning technique, offer a computationally low complexity algorithm capable of detecting associated sets of single nucleotide polymorphisms (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s) of arbitrary size, including modern genome‐wide <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> scans. However, interpretation of the importance of an individual SNP within these trees can present challenges. We present a new decision tree algorithm denoted as Bagged Alternating Decision Trees (BADTrees) that is based on identifying common structural elements in a bootstrapped set of Alternating Decision Trees (ADTrees). The algorithm is order <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi21608-math-0001.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:gepi21608:equation:gepi21608-math-0001" />, where <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> is the number of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s considered and <jats:italic>k</jats:italic> is the number of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s in the tree constructed. Our simulation study suggests that <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BAD</jats:styled-content>Trees have higher power and lower type I error rates than <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ADT</jats:styled-content>rees alone and comparable power with lower type I error rates compared to logistic regression. We illustrate the application of these data using simulated data as well as from the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>upus <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>arge <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ssociation Study 1 (7,822 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s in 3,548 individuals). Our results suggest that <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BADT</jats:styled-content>rees hold promise as a low computational order algorithm for detecting complex combinations of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> and environmental factors associated with disease.</jats:p>

title: Bootstrap Aggregating of Alternating Decision Trees to Detect Sets of <scp>SNP</scp>s That Associate With Disease
